I finally got the sugar cookies made. We found some corn-free powdered sugar at Trader Joe's (really wish we had one of those closer than 2 hours away.) I'm going over to a friend from church's house on Tuesday to help her with converting recipes since her son has several allergies, so I wanted to make cookies the kid could have too, which definitely upped the complexity. The kid is allergic to wheat, nuts, dairy and eggs. That plus my corn allergy and dye-free decision made the baking interesting to say the least. I had a recipe that had plenty of substitution ideas, and I know enough about all of the main allergens to know what to do, and we had the ingredients, it just led to a very crumbly dough. Subbing out milk is not typically an issue in recipes, and a chia seed egg actually works quite well, but between a corn allergy and dairy allergy, it meant no butter or butter substitute. The main butter substitute contains corn, and butter contains dairy. So I was left with oil, which does not work quite as well for cookies. It didn't help that that dough was initially very crumbly, so I kept adding oil and working with it and ended up adding a shade too much, which meant my perfectly cut shapes became unrecognizable when baked. But they still tasted good, and the icing tasted fine too, even with the natural food coloring. It was also good to know I can bake and compensate for a variety of allergens, though I'll be glad to have my butter to cook with for the second batch, as I think it will make it a lot easier (I was going a bit nuts when the cookies kept breaking before I could get them on the cookie sheet before figuring out to add more oil.)

The recipe made about 3 dozen cookies, and with it being egg free, I could actually eat the raw cookie dough for a change. :-) Plus we have plenty of cookies to keep some and give the rest away. One of the guys in my church group is gluten intolerant and hasn't had sugar cookies in years, so part of the second batch will go to him. I look forward to being able to hand him a container of cookies he can eat next Sunday, especially since his wife has apparently been teasing him with store bought sugar cookies lately (something common in families where only one person has an allergy, and I'm thankful Chris doesn't do that.)

The only issue I still have with the cookies is that the icing doesn't set. I think I've had that problem with other homemade icing using normal food coloring, so I don't think it's the dye, but I'm not really sure what to do about it either.

Can't sleep. Since I starting writing this in my head as I was laying in bed, I figured I might as well get up and actually write it out. 

I went off bc as of the beginning of May. I found out it could be contributing to my reflux, which I was desperately trying to control without meds, and I never got a clear answer as to whether mine contained corn. Ever since then my body has decided from mid-cycle on it's going to have PMS. Apparently said decision is lasting more than just last month, hence the insomnia and overly reflective emotionalness. 

Twice today I spoke about music and my idea to use my music degree for small group lessons since it's likely the music programs around here will be decimated by the huge chunk of state funding the governor is taking away from the K-12 schools. It's an idea I've had since getting my music degree, just not one I had overly thought through. Now, despite my willingness to toss it out as a possible way to earn money from home, I feel even less qualified. I haven't picked up my trombone for more than a practice session or two once or twice a year since my Senior recital. Every time I do I'm reminded of all the ways my embouchure and playing is wrong, and I get frustrated, then busy, and the horn stays in its case for months at a time. For a while I was a little better with keyboard, but it's been the better part of a year for that even. Yet a part of me misses music so much - I just lack the confidence (and time) to pursue it. I peaked in college, and it's unlikely I'll ever get myself back to that point. And yet to get to that point I made myself want to quit music through the endless practice sessions and disappointing lessons. Being a music major was both the best and worst decision I ever made. It made me the best I could be, yet forever tinted my love of music. 

But not everything was bad. Tonight I thought about Willard HS band camp and the other sectional teachers I met there. I wondered what they were up to now, especially the amazing drummer/marimba player who I actually met up with again when I visited U of Toledo (his alma mater) when I was considering going there for law school. He had since gone on to seminary, and I lost track of him after moving to PA. I know the other two girls have since gotten married, one rather abruptly, but I know little more than that. Like so many people, they came into my life for a brief time, then left. For a while we kept in contact, but that faded. Even if I could find them on facebook or if they suddenly revived their xangas, we would be strangers to each other; band camp has long since passed, as has graduation, and we're each either still playing/teaching or doing something entirely different. 

Perhaps an even harder memory are the kids. My 6th grade drummers from student teaching, who could barely keep a steady beat the last time I saw them, have just graduated from high school. My high school kids, especially the Cedarville HS kids I worked with for over a year, are well into college or whatever paths they chose, and some have since even graduated from there. I have no idea where any of them are at, what they chose to do with their lives, and sometimes I wish I knew. Wish I knew if they stuck with band, what fields they chose to study after school, who they grew up to be. 

It's hard, keeping up with people, trying to do more than just stay in touch and rely on memories from a prior time in life. So much changes, even in a few months. I know I can't keep up with everyone, yet at times I still desire to try, or at least to know. I think that's why I have so many facebook friends (352 and counting, and all but a dozen or so are people I've known in real life-the ones I only know online are those I've had hours of online discussions with at some point), just to be able to check in on people and see what has happened with them. It's deceptive - you don't really know the person anymore - but it's more than nothing; it's at least some way of connecting and seeing a peek into their life. And there's always the possibility of reigniting the friendship, even if it's only a glimmer of one. 

It's been five or six years since most of us last made laps around Cedar Lake (a proposition more difficult to do now with the new Bible building.) So much has changed from our college years. Sometimes I miss it. Not the classes or the trying to get the best practice spot or especially not the juries each quarter/semester. But I miss the relationships. The staying up late chatting in our rooms, the walks around the lake at night, sitting on the benches having serious conversations, the sometimes literally bouncing off the walls in the hallway til someone told us to be quiet. Like so many good things I fondly remember (conveniently forgetting the hard parts), there are times that I mourn. Mourn that I didn't realize what I had then, didn't take it fully in, did not appreciate it as much as I should have. But sometimes I know I did treasure it, realizing that time was limited and it would pass; even so it does not stop the desire to go back, even for a moment. I miss you guys. 

That's not to say life isn't good, it's just different. Hard in a different way. But it's been a hard few years. Ever since leaving Cedarville my life has been turned upside down a number of times. Often by choices I've made, and some of those have not been good choices. Not everything has been a bad turning upside down, but everything has been challenging. Challenging in a way my memory tends to forget in time, such that my memory makes past events seem better, easier than they actually were. Before long law school will be a blip on the radar of my life, and the drudgery of studying for the bar exam will be overshadowed by the next big event. And I try to turn my focus to making friends with the people in my life now, and maintaining those of my closest friends from college such that past memories are not the only things we have to share. Not an easy task, especially when struggles are not so easily shared across wires and phone lines, and each of us has a life separate from the others. 

The local minor league baseball game must be over. I hear what sounds like thunder but isn't, so it must be fireworks. I've only heard it once before, when I was up this late desperately trying to write a paper required for graduation. That was over a month ago. It's crazy how fast time flies sometimes. 

And with that I'll end this rambly and somewhat depressing post. Not sure how many people even check LJ these days anyway.

As of Tuesday I start my official bar exam preparation. I started a bit earlier b/c the official start time for the course was last Monday, and we were in a cabin w/o internet so I opted to do what I could before we left, then start the official stuff late and play catch-up. May not have been the best choice since I will likely be making a trip out to Ohio for my Mom's surgery in June. We're supposed to study 6-8 hours a day with the provided material (it's a course - law school doesn't teach you what you need to know for the bar exam so you have to take a $1400-3000 10-wk crash course to learn all the stuff the profs never taught you) and an addition 2-4 hours a day reviewing on your own to make sure you memorize all of it. The test itself is 2 days long. The first day is 300 multiple choice questions - 6 hours, in two parts, 150 questions per 3 hours - though the questions are all short paragraphs of facts so it takes 30+ seconds just to read the question. The second day is 6 essays plus a performance test - 2 essays plus the performance test in the morning 3 hours session, 4 essays in the afternoon block. The performance test is where the bar examiners will provide a small folder worth of case materials - could be anything you'd get in a legal setting - and will outline a specific task for you to do based on those materials, such as write a certain type of document to be filed or come up with an outline of the legal arguments to pursue in the case. Of course you only get an hour and half to read and digest everything, plus write out your answer. Needless to say, I will be glad when it's all over. The bar exam is the last week of July. 

Of course, come August I'm not sure what I'll be doing with my life. The bar exam results won't be out until October, and with the economy down, "might-be" attorneys generally aren't being hired. I have to pass the bar first. There are several options, though none of the standard ones are things I'd like to do. I am considering doing some crochet/sewing items and trying to sell them online, though who knows if that will make any sort of profit. At this point it's a "wait and see" since with the way things have been so far this year, who knows what will be going on at the time. It's driving me a little nuts not to know, but at the same time, not having it cemented means the thing I hope might work out still could (and no, I'm not being more specific than that at this point.)

Ok, so upon more thought, and a gracious comment by Kelly, I decided to go ahead and do the online food blog, for now. http://glutenfree2010.wordpress.com/ I decided to go with something completely separate from every other blog I have, with the thought that this could actually become a helpful for the gluten-free community. I think I'll probably post all of our recipes there, so while the baking is probably more complicated than anyone here would want to deal with (having a dozen different flours and starches around is expensive) some of the other recipes might be good (like our quiche and chili recipes, which don't really take any special ingredients.) One word of caution is that gluten-free flours and starches don't substitute 1:1 for wheat flour in recipes. This is why I've mostly modified already gluten-free recipes rather than modifying "normal" recipes. I might tackle that later on, but for now I'm still learning exactly what combination of flours is good for which type of baking. If there's only a small amount of flour called for (under 1 cup) you could probably substitute all purpose flour for it, but overall I don't know enough to convert it exactly.

So I've been obsessed with figuring out all the dos and don'ts for a gluten-free diet. The snow days have given me time to check out all the products I currently eat or our in our home. There's a lot of "nos" but actually not quite as many as I originally thought perhaps - the verdict is still out of a few products using vague ingredients that I originally labeled as "no" but might be ok. (the problem is while wheat has to be labeled by FDA regs, other sources of gluten don't have to be, i.e. barley, malt, oats, rye, and a lot of ingredients are derived from one of those latter sources but show up vaguely as "natural/artifical flavors" or "food starch", but you don't know if the individual product uses an acceptable source or an unacceptable source. A lot of times the internet has conflicting info as well, so I've started calling manufacturers or getting on their websites to find out. I have a Dr. appointment next week, and I'm going to have a whole slew of questions for her I think. Here's a video I came across explaining more about Celiac and how prevalent but undiagnosed it actually is. Apparently it can cause a significant number of chronic diseases and disorders. YouTube explanation Here's a link to the University of Chicago site with information as well: Celiac I was happy to find that Wegmans, a local grocery chain typically considered more upscale, has a little marker on all of its store brand products that label if mainline products are gluten free. This is extremely helpful in buying things like marinades and dressings, since the "gluten-free marketed" products cost 2-3 times as much as a normal mainline product. And despite my initial concern b/c of the upscale nature of the store, the actual prices are comparable to the grocery stores I normally shop, so I guess I get to switch stores partly now. Chris found this morning in the pamphelet I picked up on Celiac (sitting in a rack with other phamphelets on various food allergies)that the store publishes a weekly set of recipes and makes sure one of them is Celiac friendly. I think the employees are all trained in food allergens too b/c when I mentioned Celiac or gluten-free, they all knew what I was talking about. So that was cool, and made my shopping experience much easier. Plus the store itself is just fun. It looks like a castle from the outside and inside has all sorts of random things, like a small model train that runs on a suspended track along the length of the store. I also found a heath foods store not too far away that carries all sorts of gluten-free things that are much harder to find, like soy sauce and teriyaki sauce (because the whole process to make them is different, it's not just substituting ingredients.) The health foods store actually had a baked goods section and sold gluten-free muffins and brownies and such, with a sign that said they would make to order cakes sufficient to deal with any food allergy, including Celiac, and had a folder with a list of the products in their store that are marked gluten free. Granted, the price is significantly more, but it's good to know I could go there to pick up rarer objects or even order a birthday cake.

I just found out that a prof at my school is doing research on an area of law I kinda wanted to specialize in - collaborative practice in public interest family law. I could potentially be a research assistant for her on this project, as she's been short on time to make any progress. This could lead to lots of good things, not just potential law review article topics, but major publication and possibly creating a program in the Harrisburg area, since the research would be along the lines of what obstacles there are to the programs and how to overcome them. Makes me happy that there is someone else around with this oddball idea who sees it as legitimate. :-) So maybe having class from 6-9p tonight wasn't as bad as I'd thought it would be. 

Yes, I'm a law geek. 

For the record, collaborative practice is when both sides have an attorney and everyone sits around the table to negotiate a solution to the legal issue. It's most commonly used in divorce cases. The difficulties are due to the high emotions of the people involved, but the idea is for the attorneys to have full disclosure and represent their parties interest but work for a compromise that would be doable for both sides, making it more like a big problem solving session(s) than confrontational. The biggest issue is that due to the inherent nature of how the system works, if the practice falls through, then neither of the attorneys involved in collaborative practice can take the case to litigation. This is a difficulty for legal services clients because legal services attorneys are difficult to come by so to have to find two other attorneys if the collaborative practice falls through isn't feasible currently. To not have the clause where the attorneys step away if it goes to litigation means that one party can attempt to have the upper hand b/c you have to prep for litigation which means there wouldn't be full disclosure and the whole thing snowballs apart. So, it's generally accepted that collaborative practice, while a nice, low-cost option,  just isn't realistic in public interest settings. I don't buy that, so it's exciting to have the possibility of collaborating with a professor who also doesn't buy it and maybe be able to create workable solutions. :-) :-) :-)

A small breakdown of the strengths and weaknesses of both schools:

strong International Law program
listens to student input

study abroad programs
multiple exchange programs

very well known within the New Jersey/Philly area

In other news...literally the news this time, the Supreme Court is down to the last week of this term, and thus we shall be seeing decisions on controversial cases come out this week. Three such decisions came out today. One of them few people not in politics probably care about - Federal Election Commission v. Wisconsin Right to Life. While I haven't had the chance to read the case in full yet (the library emailed me and said they had a copy of Battlestar Galatica 2.5 in so I watched that tonight instead of reading case law) the basics of the case include the ability of certain groups to advertise within a specific time frame of an election. Basically, corporations couldn't pay for ads or other broadcasts that promote a candidate or issues that mention candidates within 60 days of a general election or 30 days of a primary election. As you can likely imagine, there's a 1st amendment free speech issue here.

In the case at hand, the broadcast was urging citizens to contact their senators regarding a proposed judicial filibuster (coughAlitocough) and ask them to oppose the filibuster. Well, it just so happened that one of the Senators was up for reelection, and this ad fell within the 30 days before the primary election. So it was illegal to show them, even though the action promoted had little to do with the election. Thus arose a case as the Wisconsin Right to Life organization proposed that the restriction violated First amendment freedom of speech. The Supreme Court ruled that the restrictions were unconstitutional since they violated freedom of speech in not allowing ads to be run in which the message was not campaign advocacy. For those who care - it falls under the legal test of compelling state interest because it's a burden on political speech, and thus the government has to prove that there is a compelling interest in regulating political speech in this manner and that the regulation is narrowly tailored to not catch anything outside of that specific interest. The compelling interest is that of denying ads compelling voters to vote a specific way close to election time, and the court sees that interest as compelling. However, the ad in question doesn't fit into that specific interest, and yet the regulations bans it, so the regulation is not narrowly tailored enough, and thus the regulation is unconstitutional as applied in this particular case.

Now why it took the Supreme Court two months to come up with that, I'm not entirely sure...The end result: 6-3, with two concurring opinions and a dissent - so much for Roberts' desire for unity. Kennedy and Souter joined the conservatives, and oddly enough, no one completely agreed with Roberts' majority opinion, hence the two concurring opinions. Guess everyone had to have their say.

The other two cases are much more interesting to the general populace and thus would require a greater discussion.
